page.title: 07LOCAL HOUSING 6
page.content:
The Lordship of Hope suffered greatly during the Civil War (1642-9), as did most of England and Wales, and it is mentioned in 1652 that 'the towne of Hope now decayid who sumtime burgesid and privilegid'. {(Local history)}
The area's wealth of{housing}continued to prosper in the 18th century. Rhyddyn Hall was founded by the Glynne family, one of which married William Gladstone, the eminent statesman. Although some of it dates from the 13th century, its most striking feature is its fine Georgian north face. Hope Hall, built in 1756 by the Rector of Westbury, but now destroyed, and Hartsheath Hall, built in 1823 by an eminent architect, Charles Matthews, and still standing in its full glory, also contribute to the architecture inspired by that era.
